commit_list.message: Fixed exception problems, and made it so the paths are expanded.
commit_list.repo_description: A simple python script that can pull in a "bundle" file, and compile it to a single output file. Think make, but for plain text.

commit_list.message: Needed to remember to reset the currentsection on a reload, otherwise it's possible that changes to the underlying file might get processed improperly.

commit_list.message: Cleaned up all of those for(var iâ€¦) loops
Refactor param parsing, started on click rules.
Fixed key presses so that if you don't supply a list, it fires on ANY key press.
Updated documentation to match new API.
The Add method now requires a document element. This keeps us from traversing the entire DOM for each state transition.
Switched the state transitions to use a statemap, and not a gigantic pile of for loops. Much cleaner code, much faster code.
Added keypress support. Did NOT add keyup/keydown, because that's way more complex.
Basic functionality implemented, with a SM demo.
Not bothering to pre-optimize. Just going to fetch states as needed. We'll worry about scaling later.
Wait, that was really stupid. I'm not doing this that way. At all.
Stubbed out initial classes. Not sure how much of this will stick around.

commit_list.message: And I never saved the readme which changes the slides link from the HTML-version to the PDF. Now we have a PDF version of the slides for ease of reading, because seriously, PPT sucks and so does Keynote's HTML export.
Added a PPT version, which may have some visual flaws, because PPT sucks.
Whups, screwed up some stuff with aside/figure (it should be a figure on the side, not an aside)
Ditched the HTML slides, switched to PDF version.
There we are. The core is done, including the slides.
Really cranking through the demos, now that the first leg is finished. Also doing some touch-ups so that things play more neatly.
Back to making slides for the actual presentation, now that I have the final demo completed. As I work on the presentation, I'll go back and fill in tutorial code by slicing up the finished CMDB.
Deleting now properly updates the view. Little more style tweaking.
Screwed up the alternating rows. Fixed now.
Applied some styling to the demo. It's still ugly, but not dog ugly.
Whoops, did I nest my tutorial in itself? Yes, I did.
Added licensing information. Look, now you can actually use these assets.
Some styling, and now we're basically feature complete. This covers pretty much all of the core Knockout features.
I really need to document the licensing differences.
Started doing a little styling, and fixing up some of the code.
Cake/Icing picker works, with some CSS to style.
Added a custom binding to handle image loading.

Skipping ahead to actually build the final product, now that I have a good idea of what the end goal should look like. Applied by craptastic graphic design skills to start building some placeholder images. They suck.
Started basic appearance bindings and expression bindings
Started basic appearance bindings and expression bindings
Dropdowns completed, with some object examples.
Added HTML version of the presentation, since Keynote is pretty niche.
Updated the readme to clarify purpose.
Select boxes, cleaned up commentary and fixed a bug in the ObservableArrays demo
Explained binding contexts, added HTML comments to better explain it.
Fixed the observable arrays. Started adding the slides.

I am apparently an idiot

GitX is really fucking my shit.
Adding up through observable arrays. I really did mean to do more frequent commits, here. Stupid GitX tool is full of lies. The Command Line is better.

Merge pull request #116 from evandentremont/patch-1

Changes pre tags to use whitespace: normal, which should fix behavior of code blocks on some browsers.

repo_list.description: An Elixir-based interactive fiction tool that uses a simple, extensible DSL driven by Elixir macros
A markov-chain replacement for GamerGaters, using a data file scraped from /r/KotakuInAction. It posts to /r/GamerGhazi.
:ticket: A list of awesome conferences
A simple python script that can pull in a "bundle" file, and compile it to a single output file. Think make, but for plain text.
A RESTful Python client for the BusTime API
Cassanova (or CSV for short) is a distributed, CSV-oriented database.
A ChucK app controllable over OSC which will emulate a chorus of chanting voices.
A simple rolling average beat detector in ChucK.
CSS State Machine
It's like MongoDB, but instead of JSON, it uses CSV.
An EveryTwit Markov bot that scrapes twitter and vomits meaningless garbage.
I needed a tool to quickly generate various kinds of Fiasco setups, especially including the ability to generate non-standard setups. This is the (start) of that tool.
A floating-point based one dimensional cellular automata. Supports all Wolfram rules using integers.
My Hammerspoon (a window manager) configuration. It's unlikely that anybody else will care about this.
Hashed Words
A stupid Python script that comments on an improv show- live!
A simple introduction to Knockout
Classroom exercises for Continuous Delivery
A simple processing sketch that creates an interesting video effect.
This is a tool for mangling an input audio file to create cut-up, glitched audio.
I like using plaintext files as notes. I'm writing my own CLI version of NotationalVelocity.
A simple OpenCV "Hello World" that lets you bounce a ball on the screen using the camera.
An art toy that generates random patterns based on orbital harmonics.
A Processing Host and an OpenGL Shader which will be controlled by OSC
Scripts and modules for helping with a plain-text workflow.
A random looping synth written in Sonic-Pi and Processing
A simple sample Ajax/Rails example, using a DataContext-style API.
The August BYOC Contest
Converts text to an image in a C-64 compatible color palette.
Simple vagrant example for standing up a ruby box
An OpenCV-based, Python2.7 system that watches objects in a camera's view and emits OSC messages based on those events.
